history.content:
This class has been taught forever by Lustig who made it a very heavy project class. There were a ton of labs that took forever and a very involved final project. It was probably the single highest workload class in the department because it's both conceptually challenging while also being workload heavy. I can't really think of any other EECS class that has this combination.

However, Ramchandran is teaching it next semester and he's an info theory person. Unless he borrows Lustig's materials, he is definitely going to make the class more reflective of a traditional DSP class with more emphasis on filter bank theory than practical DSP projects. If you look at the last time he taught it in '08, the class was pset/exam only. Whether or not this is a good thing is up to you. But DSP has also changed in the 12 years since, so I definitely wouldn't expect the class to be the same. He might incorporate projects; it's hard to say.

If you're interested in building stuff like a sonar or a wireless modem, I would wait for Lustig to teach it. However, if you're big into systems theory, now's the best time to take it without getting bogged down by the pesky coding projects/labs (my personal view).

It was probably the single highest workload class in the department because it's both conceptually challenging while also being workload heavy. I can't really think of any other EECS class that has this combination.

However, Ramchandran is teaching it next semester and he's an info theory person. Unless he borrows Lustig's materials, he is definitely going to make the class more reflective of a traditional DSP class with more emphasis on filter bank theory than practical DSP projects. If you look at the last time he taught it in '08, the class was pset/exam only. Whether or not this is a good thing is up to you. But DSP has also changed in the 12 years since, so I definitely wouldn't expect the class to be the same. He might incorporate projects; it's hard to say.

If you're interested in building stuff like a sonar or a wireless modem, I would wait for Lustig to teach it. However, if you're big into systems theory, now's the best time to take it without getting bogged down by the pesky coding project (my personal view).

I can’t speak of it myself — since I always instructed it, never took it. But in terms of load, we have made significant efforts in reducing it considerably— in particular, last semester when the class went on line.

While the labs can be time consuming, it gives you a better perspective of what is DSP in practice, rather than on paper, and empowers you to pursue your own projects.

I believe Kannan will continue with the labs, and I’m going to help in that. As to the rest of the material— that’s the beauty about Berkeley— each instructor puts a bit of him/herself into the class, so of course it would be different.

Why take it? See post #10901
Conclusion: Take EE123

Miki

children.subject: A link to the post that Professor Lustig's recommended, @10901  for easy clicking.

EE 128 is definitely a good option if you're interested in control theory or robotics. 123 is about the practical applications of the discrete-time algorithms you learn about in 120, while 128 will expand upon the continuous-time concepts, as well as other related topics like controllability and stability. 128 will also further develop the state-space approach to LTI systems that you learn about briefly in 16B, as well as stuff that comes out of the state-space approach such as LQR.

What would the workload of the 2 be like then ? 

(For context, I'm in 151 and 7b and struggling with the workload in the online format)

In that case, I would stick with an easier class, as 128 is also high workload. Not as high as 123, but still high. Maybe something from the CS side. All of the 12x classes aside from 120 are pretty difficult. I think the only EE class I've taken that would translate well to the online format is EE 130. Are you interested in device physics at all?

Maybe something on the CS side like 188? Depends on what you're interested in.
If you like graphics CS184 could work as well.
Any recommendations on what other class to take with this one next sem, given the workload and online format? I wanted to take 127 but the lectures conflict.

history.content: Contemplating whether to take this course next semester. I liked 120 a lot and am definitely a more robotics focused person, and was wondering what the course load is like, and why I should take this course?
history.subject: What is EE123 like?
